verses.text: When the wedding feast was over, Tobit called his son Tobias and said to him, 'My child, see to it that you give the man who went with you his wages, and add something extra.'
verses.comment: Tobit models the importance of just recompense for service, reflecting the broader biblical principle of paying workers fairly (see Leviticus 19:13; Deuteronomy 24:14-15). This act of justice is also an act of mercy, demonstrating faithfulness in small things.

verses.text: He replied, 'Father, it would not harm me to give him half of all that I brought back, for he led me safely and healed my wife, brought the money back with me, and healed you as well.'
verses.comment: Tobias shows gratitude and generosity, virtues that are foundational in the life of faith. This echoes Jesus' call to freely give in response to the gifts we've received (Matt. 10:8).

verses.text: The old man said, 'He truly deserves it.'
verses.comment: Tobit's affirmation highlights the importance of recognizing the value of the good done by others.

verses.text: So Tobias called Raphael and said, 'Take half of everything you brought back, as your wages. Go in peace.'
verses.comment: Generosity brings blessing; giving freely leads to spiritual and material enrichment (Prov. 11:25).

verses.text: Then Raphael called them both aside privately and said to them, 'Bless God and give Him thanks before all the living for the good things He has done for you; bless and praise His name. Declare to all people the deeds of God as they deserve, and do not hesitate to give Him thanks.'
verses.comment: The angel exhorts them to public thanksgiving, a central biblical theme (Psalm 34:1; Psalm 96:2). Giving witness to God's work is a responsibility of all believers, reflecting liturgical worship and testimony.

verses.text: It is good to keep the secret of a king, but it is honorable to reveal the works of God. Do what is good, and no harm will come to you.
verses.comment: Divine works are to be proclaimed, not hidden. This foreshadows the call to bear witness to God's light (cf. Matt. 5:16). Secrecy is sometimes prudent, but the deeds of God bring Him glory through open proclamation.

verses.text: Prayer with fasting is good, but better than both is almsgiving with righteousness. A little with righteousness is better than much with injustice. It is better to give alms than to store up gold,
verses.comment: The text joins prayer, fasting, and almsgiving as key pillars of a holy life—practices explicitly recalled by Jesus (Matt. 6). Material possessions are to serve acts of mercy. True righteousness unites inner devotion and outward charity, reminiscent of Acts 10:4, where Cornelius’ prayers and alms go up as a memorial before God.

verses.text: for almsgiving saves from death and purges away every sin. Those who give alms will enjoy a full life,
verses.comment: Almsgiving is linked to the forgiveness of sins—a subtle affirmation of how works of mercy, done in faith, play a role in salvation. This is foreshadowed in Luke 11:41 and seen in Acts 10:4. It demonstrates an intimate connection between faith, action, and God’s grace, prefiguring the ongoing role of charity in the Christian life.

verses.text: but those who practice sin and wrongdoing are enemies of themselves.
verses.comment: Sin has consequences not only spiritually but even in this life, as those who persist in wrongdoing bring harm upon themselves (cf. Prov. 1:18).

verses.text: I will reveal to you the whole truth and hide nothing from you. I have already said that it is good to keep the secret of a king, but it is honorable to reveal the works of God.
verses.comment: Spiritual revelation is meant for the good of the people of God. The angel prepares them for a deeper unveiling, reminiscent of New Testament patterns where things hidden are brought to light (Matt. 10:26).

verses.text: So now, when you and Sarah prayed, it was I who brought your prayers before the presence of the Holy One. And when you buried the dead, I was with you also.
verses.comment: Here the angel reveals a mediatorial role, carrying prayers to God—the type of angelic intercession seen in Revelation 8:4. This demonstrates the communion between heaven and earth, and the effectiveness of works of mercy (such as burying the dead) in God's sight.

verses.text: It was I who presented your prayers and your acts of charity before the Lord. When you buried the dead, I was by your side.
verses.comment: The angel reiterates the connection between the works of mercy and their spiritual significance. God regards both our prayers and charitable acts as acceptable at His throne. This hints at an economy of grace in which God invites us to cooperate with Him (cf. Eph. 2:10).

verses.text: When you did not hesitate to get up and leave your meal to go and bury the dead, your action was not hidden from me; I was with you.
verses.comment: Self-sacrifice in performing works of mercy, even at personal cost, is particularly pleasing to God. This is echoed throughout the Scriptures, where God remembers the righteous (Heb. 13:16).

verses.text: So now God sent me to heal you and your daughter-in-law Sarah.
verses.comment: God uses messengers as instruments of healing, prefiguring the many healings performed by Christ and the Apostles (Matt. 9:35). This also subtly reinforces the mediation of grace through instruments appointed by God.

verses.text: I am Raphael, one of the seven holy angels who present the prayers of the saints and enter into the presence of the glory of the Holy One.
verses.comment: Raphael's identity reveals a biblical view of angels as both messengers and intercessors for the people of God. This is directly paralleled in Revelation 8:2-4. The collective witness of saints and angels before God underlines the unity of worship and prayer that spans heaven and earth.

verses.text: The two of them were shaken; they fell facedown in fear.
verses.comment: Their reverence at the angel’s revelation mirrors the awe shown throughout Scripture when humans encounter the holy (Dan. 8:17; Luke 1:12), highlighting the transcendence of heavenly messengers.

verses.text: But he said, 'Do not be afraid; peace be with you. Bless God forever.
verses.comment: The angel’s message of peace anticipates the repeated assurances given by both angels and Jesus (Luke 2:10; John 14:27). The focus remains on giving glory to God.

verses.text: For as long as I was with you, it was not by my own will, but by the will of God. Bless Him each day; sing His praises.
verses.comment: Even angels serve according to God’s command. This verse affirms both constant praise and the sovereignty of God over all spiritual beings and events.

verses.text: You saw me eat and drink, but that was only an appearance. What you saw was a vision.
verses.comment: Angels may appear in human form, though their true nature is spiritual (cf. Gen. 18:8). This prepares the way for later theological reflection on the reality of spiritual realities veiled in ordinary things.

verses.text: So now, give thanks to God. I am ascending to Him who sent me. Write down everything that has happened to you.'
verses.comment: Raphael's ascent reflects the communication between heaven and earth. ‘Write down everything’ implies the importance of sacred tradition and testimony as a means of passing on the faith (cf. Ex. 17:14; 1 John 1:3).

verses.text: Then they stood up, but could see him no more.
verses.comment: The sudden departure of Raphael parallels the disappearances of Christ after His resurrection (Luke 24:31; Acts 1:9). Such moments point to God's hidden yet present providence.

verses.text: They kept blessing God and giving Him thanks. They publicly proclaimed all the works He had done for them.
verses.comment: The chapter closes with doxology and proclamation—appropriate ends for any genuine encounter with divine grace. Public witness and continued thanksgiving become the essential marks of the faithful (cf. Ps. 9:1; Luke 2:20).
